title: SA Connect yet to get going
text:
SA Connect yet to get going September 16 2015 at 01:33pm By Nicola Mawson, IOL Business Editor Comment on this story REUTERS File image of connected schools. 
Johannesburg - SA’s ambitious plan to connect the entire population to the Internet is seemingly stuttering along as the first phase has yet to be completed, and the second is due to start next year. 
This was revealed this morning at a breakfast briefing hosted by BMI-Techknowledge for members of the ICT industry. 
SA’s need to ubiquitous broadband at faster speeds is evident when one considers how few people have access to reliable connectivity. Broadband has the potential to boost economic growth and a stat oft cited from the World Bank is that the economy will gain 1 percent for every 10 increase in broadband. 
BMI-Techknowledge telecoms specialist Tim Parle painted a picture of the low levels of connectivity and speed South Africans enjoy. 
He notes South Africa has a population of 54 million people, based on Statistics SA’s latest numbers, but only 11 percent of the 15.6 million South African homes access Internet at home on a device other than a phone. 
By comparison, Parle notes, 32.6 million South Africans older than 16 have cellphones, a figure that is evenly split between feature phones and smartphones. In addition, SA’s broadband speeds are lacking when compared to developed nations, he says. 
BMI-T MD Denis Smit notes there has been progress with SA Connect, but progress was held up when president Jacob Zuma shuffled the Cabinet last May. He adds the market was also caught by surprise when Zuma announced Telkom would be the lead agency for the national broadband network during Zuma’s February State of the Agency Address. 
Telkom’s role, says Smit, has yet to be clarified because no-one knows whether it will handle the whole project, or outsource parts. 
Smit notes the first phase of SA Connect has not been completed as yet, and phase two is due to start in 2016. However, as the first phase has not been completed, it is not clear whether further funding will be forthcoming. 
The first phase has a budget of R28.5 million according to Treasury’s latest budget figures. So far, an additional R770 has been earmarked for the project. 
Smit says this is not enough, pointing out the private sector will spend about R20 billion in one year on broadband. He adds there is little in the form of “new funds” available to government because the fiscus is under pressure and belts are being tightened. 
There has been clear progress in some areas, but progress is poor overall, says Smit. He says the next 6 to 12 months will be a tipping point. 
Tersia Smit, a public sector and telecoms analyst at BMI-T, points out government will spend around R15 billion on ICT in the 2017/18 financial year, but the bulk of this will go into aspects such as computer equipment. She says, as this spending is on internal systems, it is not clear where the money will come from the the broadband plan. 
Media reports have previously pegged the amount to be spent at around R98 billion. 
Tersia Smit also notes there is a lack of clarity around which money is being spent on what ICT projects. “There is no one view, it’s very difficult to see what government is doing. It’s all over the place.” 
IOL
